learning.title: Beginner Guide
learning.subtitle: Everything you need to succeed with Facebook Ads
learning.campaign_definition: The container that holds your objective (Sales, Leads, Traffic) and budget strategy
learning.adset_definition: The targeting settings - who sees your ads, when, and where
learning.ad_definition: The creative - what people actually see (image/video + text)
learning.ads_per_adset: 3-5 ads per targeting is recommended. This lets Facebook optimize delivery without diluting your budget.
learning.new_campaign_vs_adset: Create a new campaign for different objectives (Sales vs Leads). Create a new targeting for different audiences (US vs UK, or different ages).
learning.budget_testing: Start with $5-20/day per targeting for testing
learning.budget_scaling: When scaling, increase budget by 20% every 2-3 days if performing well
learning.when_to_pause: Consider pausing ads with CTR below 1%, CPA 2x your target, or no conversions in 3+ days
learning.objective_tip: Your campaign objective tells Facebook what action you want users to take. Always select the objective that matches your actual business goal - if you want purchases, choose Sales; if you want leads, choose Leads.
learning.objective_tip_box: Target what you really want the user to do - Facebook optimizes for exactly what you ask for
learning.pixel_step_3: Name your pixel and enter your website URL
learning.pixel_step_4: Choose installation method (Partner integration or manual code)
learning.pixel_step_5: Test your pixel is firing correctly using the Pixel Helper browser extension
learning.lead_step_1: Go to Facebook Ads Manager and create a new campaign
learning.lead_step_3: Set up your targeting (budget, audience, placements)
learning.lead_step_4: At the Ad level, select "Instant Form" as your lead method
learning.lead_step_5: Click "Create Form" - add your questions (name, email, phone, custom)
learning.lead_step_6: Set up your thank you screen, then publish your campaign
learning.lead_youtube_query: How To Create Facebook Instant Forms
learning.ads_per_adset_tip: 3-5 ads per targeting is the sweet spot
learning.pixel_intro: A Facebook Pixel tracks actions on your website (purchases, sign-ups, etc.) so Facebook can optimize your ads for conversions.
learning.lead_intro: Lead forms let people submit their contact info directly on Facebook without leaving the app. Great for collecting leads quickly.
learning.higher_intent_tip: Choose "Higher Intent" form type if you want more qualified leads (they have to confirm their info)
learning.mistake_too_many_ads: Too many ads in one targeting dilutes your budget across too many variations
learning.mistake_narrow_targeting: Too narrow targeting (audience under 100k) limits Facebook's optimization
learning.mistake_learning_phase: Changing ads during learning phase resets the optimization process
learning.mistake_no_testing: Not testing creative variations means you might miss better performing options

tips.budget_testing: Start with $10-20/day for testing new audiences
tips.audience_size: Keep audience size 500k-2M for best results
tips.ad_variations: Use 3-5 ad variations to let Facebook find winners
tips.budget_increase: Increase budget by max 20% at a time to avoid resetting the learning phase
tips.pause_criteria: Consider pausing ads with CTR below 1% or no conversions in 3 days

wizard.conversion_optimize_leads: Track when visitors convert on your website

status_modal.pause_campaign_explanation: Pausing this campaign will stop all ads inside it. Your audience won't see any of these ads until you resume.
status_modal.pause_adset_explanation: Pausing this targeting will stop all ads inside it. Other targeting groups in the campaign will continue running.
status_modal.pause_ad_explanation: Pausing this ad will stop showing it to your audience. Other ads in the targeting will continue running.
status_modal.resume_campaign_explanation: Resuming this campaign will start showing your ads again. Make sure your budget is set correctly.
status_modal.resume_adset_explanation: Resuming this targeting will start showing its ads again. The parent campaign must also be active.
status_modal.resume_ad_explanation: Resuming this ad will start showing it again. The parent targeting and campaign must also be active.
status_modal.reassurance: You can change this back anytime - nothing is permanent.

spend.name: Spend
spend.definition: Total money spent on your ads during this period. This is the actual amount deducted from your budget.

impressions.name: Impressions
impressions.definition: How many times your ads were displayed to people. One person might see your ad multiple times.

clicks.name: Clicks
clicks.definition: Number of times people clicked on your ads. This includes clicks to your website, app, or other destinations.

ctr.name: CTR (Click-Through Rate)
ctr.definition: Percentage of people who clicked after seeing your ad. Calculated as clicks ÷ impressions × 100. Above 1% is generally good.

cpc.name: CPC (Cost Per Click)
cpc.definition: Average cost for each click on your ad. Calculated as spend ÷ clicks. Lower is more efficient.

cpm.name: CPM (Cost Per 1000 Impressions)
cpm.definition: How much you pay for every 1,000 times your ad is shown. Useful for comparing reach efficiency across campaigns.

conversions.name: Conversions
conversions.definition: Actions you care about that people take after clicking your ad - like purchases, signups, form submissions, or downloads.

cpa.name: CPA (Cost Per Acquisition)
cpa.definition: Average cost for each conversion. Calculated as spend ÷ conversions. Lower means you're getting results more efficiently.

roas.name: ROAS (Return on Ad Spend)
roas.definition: Revenue earned per dollar spent on ads. A ROAS of 3x means you earned $3 for every $1 spent. Higher is better.

conversion_rate.name: Conversion Rate
conversion_rate.definition: Percentage of clicks that became conversions. Calculated as conversions ÷ clicks × 100. Shows how well your landing page converts.

campaign.name: Campaign
campaign.definition: The top level of Facebook ads. Contains your objective (what you want to achieve) and overall budget strategy. Think of it as a folder for related targeting groups.

targeting.name: Targeting
targeting.definition: The middle level that controls WHO sees your ads, WHEN they see them, and WHERE they appear. Contains targeting, schedule, and budget settings.

ad.name: Ad
ad.definition: The actual creative that people see - your image or video, headline, text, and call-to-action button. Multiple ads can be tested within one targeting.

lookalike.name: Lookalike Audience
lookalike.definition: Facebook finds people who are similar to your existing customers or website visitors. Great for expanding reach to likely buyers.

custom_audience.name: Custom Audience
custom_audience.definition: Target people who already interacted with your business - website visitors, app users, email subscribers, or people who engaged with your content.

broad_targeting.name: Broad Targeting
broad_targeting.definition: Letting Facebook's AI find the best audience for your ads with minimal restrictions. Often performs well because the algorithm optimizes delivery.

hook_rate.name: Hook Rate
hook_rate.definition: Percentage of viewers who watched past the first 3 seconds of your video. Shows if your opening grabs attention. Above 30% is good.

hold_rate.name: Hold Rate
hold_rate.definition: Percentage of viewers who kept watching after the hook. Shows if your content maintains interest throughout the video.

fatigue.name: Ad Fatigue
fatigue.definition: When your audience has seen your ad too many times and performance starts declining. Signs include rising CPC and falling CTR. Time for fresh creative!

cookies.title: We use cookies
cookies.description: We use cookies to enhance your experience, analyze site traffic, and for marketing purposes. By clicking "Accept All", you consent to our use of cookies.
cookies.necessary_desc: Required for the website to function. Cannot be disabled.
cookies.analytics_desc: Help us understand how visitors interact with our website.
cookies.marketing_desc: Used to track visitors across websites for advertising purposes.
